Literature Review: Three-decision methods have been proposed as an alternative to the widely used null hypothesis significance testing (NHST) system. This approach views significance tests as a three-decision framework, where we either assert the sign of the parameter above or below a specified null value, or say nothing either way. Tukey (1969) viewed this as a'sensible formulation' of tests, as it allows for a more nuanced understanding of the results. In this review, we will discuss the three-decision framework and its applications in various statistical tools, including Bayesian analogs of frequentist power calculations, p-values, confidence intervals, and multiple testing corrections. We will also explore how three-decision arguments can resolve some well-known difficulties in the interpretation and criticism of testing results. Our discussion will be based on real-valued parameters, and we will provide explicit results for simple conjugate analyses. We will also examine the implications of this framework for sensitivity analysis and multiple testing corrections.
